text: Let’s be real here folks,
for the most part snakes don’t look that tough.
They can’t punch you, can’t kick you, have pretty limited
mobility, and a forked tongue?
Come on.
But nature in all of its clever,

evolutionary glory gave some
snakes the ultimate chemical
compensation: deadly venom.
(Splash)
Snake venoms carry a plethora of benefits.
For snakes anyway.
First, they help snakes both kill and immobilize their prey.

Second, some venoms help digest
and break down that prey
when it turns into a meal.
Then, venoms act as a defense
mechanism, so if predators are
trying to step, they’re going
have to face the consequences.
The rather unpleasant consequences.
In short, venoms are chemical cocktails
of proteins, including special enzymes, all of which are
custom tailored to wreak havoc on
different parts of your body.
Each component is up to something nasty,

and worst of all, the mixtures
work well together as a team.

Enzymes, as you chemistry buffs
already know, help speed up,
or catalyze chemical reactions.

This is why when those fangs  get a 
hold of you, bad things
can start happening very quickly.
There are four primary categories

of snake venoms with varying
effects on the body.

Hemotoxic venoms  can work
in a handful of ways.

First these toxins can target
red blood cells and blood
vessels to cause fatal bleeding.
Second, they can activate or inhibit
blood clotting in your body.
You may have seen this crazy video where these guys inject

snake venom into some blood and
it turns into a bloody gel

biscuit, that’s blood clotting in action
right there.
These venoms have enzymes that speedily convert a blood protein
called prothrombin into thrombin.

Thrombin then helps another
compound called fibrin to start
sticking together, which forms clots.

What’s really crazy though is
that some species of snakes

have venoms so powerful that
they use up all of your blood
clotting resources to create little microclots.
This makes it so real, blood stopping clots
can’t form and you can bleed out.
Hemotoxins can also cause
hemorrhaging, stroke, and even heart failure.
Cytotoxins attack the site of the bite, breaking down the cells

and tissue: this venom actually
starts digesting the prey.
If you’re bitten by a snake with cytotoxin it is possible
you’ll lose that body part, so don’t get too attached.
Neurotoxins attack your nerves and brain.

They can block neurotransmitters
from reaching their appropriate receptors.

In other words, they muffle a
lot of the important chemical

messages that your body uses
regulate its own biological processes.
This can lead to paralysis and even respiratory failure.

In other cases, some neurotoxins
overload the nervous system,

over stimulating receptor cells,
ultimately leading to cell death.

And some neurotoxins actually break
break down nerve issues
just like proteolytic venoms.

Proteolytic venoms have enzymes
that make the site of a bite
undergo proteolysis which means it breaks down
proteins into smaller parts.

These nasty enzymes can target cells, blood,
and muscles,

and jump-start prey digestions, similar to
cytotoxins.

Proteolytic compounds in venom
are the granddaddy of venom
agents, with effects similar to
the other 3 classes I just mentioned.

All species of venomous snakes
contain proteolytic compounds,
and good lord do those molecules hurt.

As frightening as these venoms are, the majority
of venomous snakebites come from situations

where people are the ones bothering or mishandling
the snakes, not the other way around.

Out of the average 7500 annually
reported venomous snakebites in
the US, only around 5 people actually die each year.

They cause more deaths in warmer
climates around the world, but
snakes still don’t really deserve their scary reputation.

It also might surprise you to
know scientists look to harness
some of these venomous effects for good.

A recent example is the discovery
that certain snake venoms contain

molecules that can help break
down amyloid beta proteins,

a central cause of the onset
of Alzheimer’s disease.

Also, in 2015 researchers showed
that extracted batroxobin molecules

from venom can help clot bleeding
wounds within 20 seconds.

So you see folks, snake venoms
are a perfect example of how
chemistry can work for or against
you in a diverse range of ways.
What could kill you, could also save your life.
On the topic of venoms, the animal kingdom has a huge
range of weird chemical defenses.
We’re partial to the Hagfish’s slime-shooting action.
Let us know your favorite chemical defense in the
comments, and we might explain
how it works in a future episode.

Make sure to post any chemistry
questions in the comments,
hit the thumbs up button
and subscribe on the way out!
